intro: Let's explore how heat moves! Imagine two objects with different temperatures. What do you think happens to the heat energy between them?

questions.question: You have Object A at 80°C. If you bring it near Object B, which is at 20°C, what will happen to the heat energy?
options: Heat will flow from Object A to Object B.
Heat will flow from Object B to Object A.
No heat will flow because Object B is colder.
Heat will flow equally in both directions.
questions.hint: Think about which object has more 'heat energy' concentrated in it.

questions.question: After some time, if Object A is at 50°C and Object B is also at 50°C, what is happening to the heat flow?
options: Heat is still flowing from A to B.
Heat is still flowing from B to A.
Heat is flowing from B to A.
questions.hint: Remember the concept of thermal equilibrium.

questions.question: If Object A was at 20°C and Object B was at 80°C, in which direction would heat flow initially?
questions.hint: Heat always seeks to move from a warmer place to a cooler place.

followups: See how heat always moves from hotter to colder? This is why your hot chocolate cools down!
This movement of heat is the first step to understanding conduction, convection, and radiation.
summary: Heat energy always flows from a hotter object to a colder object until they reach the same temperature.
